message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the physical exam findings suggest a possible uterine fibroid. A benign tumor of the myometrium is the most likely cause of the asymmetrically enlarged uterus. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue would cause abnormal uterine bleeding but not necessarily an enlarged uterus. Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue and pedunculated endometrial mass would also cause abnormal uterine bleeding but not necessarily an enlarged uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest the presence of uterine fibroids, which are benign tumors of the myometrium. The enlarged, nodular uterus is consistent with this diagnosis. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue would be more likely in postmenopausal women, and abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue (endometrial hyperplasia) is associated with irregular bleeding rather than increased flow and duration. Pedunculated endometrial masses are rare and usually detected incidentally.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest she has uterine fibroids, which are benign tumors of the myometrium. The asymmetrically enlarged, nodular uterus is also consistent with this diagnosis. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue would cause abnormal bleeding but not necessarily dyspareunia or lower abdominal pain. Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue would cause abnormal bleeding but not necessarily an enlarged uterus. Pedunculated endometrial mass is a rare condition and not likely in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest an increase in the size and duration of menstrual flow and a nodular uterus consistent with a fibroid, which is a benign tumor of the myometrium. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue would involve abnormal cells, which are not mentioned in the question. Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue is suggestive of endometrial hyperplasia or cancer, which would not cause an asymmetrically enlarged uterus. Pedunculated endometrial masses are uncommon and would not cause the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an enlarged, nodular uterus, which is consistent with a benign tumor of the myometrium, or uterine fibroids. The heavy flow and dyspareunia are likely due to the size and location of the fibroids, while the cyclical abdominal pain suggests that the fibroids are hormone-responsive. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue would not cause an enlarged uterus, and abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue would not cause nodularity. A pedunculated endometrial mass would not cause an enlarged uterus either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of a benign tumor of the myometrium, also known as leiomyoma or fibroid. The asymmetrically enlarged, nodular uterus consistent in size with a 12-week gestation is a typical finding. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue is more commonly associated with abnormal vaginal bleeding in postmenopausal women. Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue is also associated with abnormal vaginal bleeding, but the patient's symptoms are more consistent with fibroids. Pedunculated endometrial mass is a rare cause of abnormal vaginal bleeding and is not as likely as fibroids in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including increased duration and flow of menses and an asymmetrically enlarged, nodular uterus, suggest a benign tumor of the myometrium, also known as uterine fibroids. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue would present with abnormal vaginal bleeding, and abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue would indicate endometrial hyperplasia or cancer. A pedunculated endometrial mass would present with abnormal vaginal bleeding but not necessarily with enlarged uterus or dyspareunia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a uterine fibroid, which is a benign tumor of the myometrium. The enlarged, nodular uterus is consistent with a fibroid. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue would cause abnormal bleeding, but it usually occurs in postmenopausal women. Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue is a symptom of endometrial cancer, but the patient’s symptoms suggest a uterine fibroid. A pedunculated endometrial mass is a rare cause of abnormal uterine bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most likely cause of the patient’s findings is a benign tumor of the myometrium, or a leiomyoma, which can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, dyspareunia, and pelvic pain. The enlarged, nodular uterus is also consistent with this diagnosis. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue would not cause an asymmetrically enlarged uterus, and it would be unlikely in a patient of this age without additional risk factors. Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue, or endometrial hyperplasia, can cause heavy bleeding but would not necessarily result in an enlarged uterus. A pedunculated endometrial mass would not cause an enlarged uterus, and would also be less likely to cause heavy bleeding consistently over several months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of abnormal menstrual flow and duration, dyspareunia, and lower abdominal pain. The enlarged, nodular uterus suggests a mass. Among the options, only a benign tumor of the myometrium (fibroid) can present with these symptoms. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue (endometrial cancer) is another possible cause, but the patient's symptoms and physical examination suggest a uterine mass rather than thickening of the endometrial lining.
